lg.l: Full in the light of morning, high upon a withered bough,
A Tui Tui. The tui is a species of bird known for its complex and melodious song. sits and calls his mate in tuneful thee and thou,
Methinks a bird of high degree, graceful, alert, and keen,
With dead-gold specks about his coat, and violet lights and green. Dead-gold specks … violet lights and green. Tui feathers have an iridescent appearance.
A speckled band, a shapely ruff, Speckled band … shapely ruff. Tui have white feathers around the neck and white tufts on the throat. about his supple throat,
As though he must be warmly kept, or would not sing a note,
And best of beauties manifold, his crisp, white feather bands, White feather “bands.” Possibly a reference to white shoulder feathers that are visible in flight.
Arranged and kept in order meet, without the use of hands.
In perfect match with his attire, his song is choice and strange,
Now soft, now harsh, now sweet, he runs through all a songbird’s range;
He stands on high and calls his mate, bright in the sun’s bright rays—
A type of that mysterious past, the unknown Maori days.
Days when the bold, bright Maori was free from Pakeha Pakeha. Pākehā is the most common Māori term for the settler population and was at times used as a term of settler self-identification. rule,
When to learn to fish and fight and swim was all he knew of school.
Looks he not back to those free days, to wish they were not done?

He may, for, like the birds and bush, his race is nearly done. Nearly done. Along with a growing number of animal extinctions, it was an increasingly common settler belief in the last decades of the 1800s that Māori were likely to die out as a distinct population.
